stream_context.summary: Kaze iterates on the papercraft-themed first course of “Return to Yoshi’s Island,” balancing Mario’s new spin-jump, redesigning the opening hub, experimenting with craft-material props, placing Yoshi Coins, and prototyping a thimble-based Shy Guy enemy while discussing shading, performance, and community feedback.

development_findings.summary: Spin-jump was nerfed (lower initial velocity, less air-turning); repeated A-mashes now add height so it feels like Smash’s down-B stall without breaking level design.
development_findings.quote: I made it so that the initial velocity is less, but mashing A gives you more height. I want this to be a very slow thing that gives you security, not free vertical cheese.

development_findings.summary: Starting hub redesigned: full cardboard castle added, styrofoam hills re-textured, Egypt area given tilting platforms.
Yoshi Coin system: each coin tied to a small ‘special interaction’ (e.g., trampoline, Peach-rescue from Shy Guys, secret cardboard flap, Bowser cut-out bridge, hidden Bob-omb cannon).
development_findings.quote: Yoshi coins are special interactions… this level doesn’t have many NPCs, so we need to be creative.

development_findings.summary: Decided all props must be plausibly hand-crafted from 1990s household materials (cardboard, styrofoam, cotton, etc.) to preserve the papercraft aesthetic and N64-era canon.
Prototype ‘thimble Shy Guy’: metal thimble body, hand-drawn mask, brown feet; Kaze built low-poly model (49–69 triangles) and custom two-cycle texture to fake metallic dimples.

Custom camera-space specular/normal trick implemented to make surfaces (e.g., styrofoam hills, thimble) shine convincingly on real N64 hardware; still debating correct terminology (normal vs bump vs specular map).
development_findings.quote: After talking to people about what a normal map actually is, I found out what I wanted wasn’t a normal map… but it is the thing I have now.

development_findings.summary: Performance test: un-optimised 7,500-poly scene (88k including text) runs at expected 30 fps on real N64; confirms headroom for additional props.
Core movement engine includes QoL fixes (long-jump jump-cancel, wall-kick speed retention, frame-perfect sparkles) and new dive-jump; source code will be made public.
development_findings.quote: Yes, the source will be public.

context_findings.summary: Kaze acknowledges ongoing learning despite deep M64 knowledge.
context_findings.quote: I think you did learn everything about M64? I mean, I am still learning things.

context_findings.summary: Expresses mild frustration with first ‘real hater’ disliking every upload, especially one accusing him of ‘destroying the environment with ChatGPT’.
States philosophy on monetisation: hacks will always be free due to legality; if allowed, would maybe sell optional cosmetics.
context_findings.quote: I never charge for my games. I wouldn’t be allowed to. If I was allowed, maybe I’d release the base game for free and you could buy a skin.

context_findings.summary: Openly crowdsources ideas from chat, embraces community creativity while setting firm design boundaries (e.g., no scissor enemy, no post-N64 IP).

biobak.summary: Replaced outdated enemy textures with new papercraft versions; ‘almost done’ with current asset batch.
Provides feedback on cloud models and polygon counts during stream.

badub.summary: Will compose adaptive music that changes by biome; Kaze waiting to hear draft.
badub.quote: I’m gonna see what music Badub is gonna come up—ideally it changes depending on which biome you’re in.

zeina.summary: Tasked with drawing new clouds; currently working on animation set 13 and cloud art.
zeina.quote: Zeina wants to draw in clouds anyway, so I’m attaching them right now.

zeina.summary: Casual, supportive on-stream banter indicates healthy personal/professional dynamic.

key_stories.title: Taming the Spin-Jump
key_stories.summary: The new spin-jump originally let players scale walls and trivialised platforming. Kaze methodically reduced its power while preserving its ‘safety-net’ feel.
key_stories.challenge: Spin-jump was ‘way too broken’, granting nearly vertical climbs.
key_stories.process: Lowered initial velocity, cut horizontal control, let repeated A-presses add height, play-tested live.
key_stories.outcome: Settled on slower stall move that no longer invalidates level design.
key_stories.key_quote: Maybe I don’t need to edit the spin jump—sure it’s a little extra height, but it gives you security if you make a mistake.

key_stories.title: Inventing the Thimble Shy Guy
key_stories.summary: Chat suggested Shy Guys; Kaze brainstormed household objects, chose a metal thimble body and built a low-poly model with fake metallic dimples.
key_stories.challenge: Needed craft-material enemies that read as Shy Guys yet obey polygon budgets.
key_stories.process: Reviewed reference photos, tested textures, tweaked N64 combine modes, reduced triangle count.
key_stories.outcome: Prototype model accepted; will harass Peach doodle to guard a Yoshi Coin.
key_stories.key_quote: I think this will look enough like a Shy Guy if I make this red, draw on the mask, and add brown feet.

key_stories.title: Dealing with a Persistent Hater
key_stories.summary: Kaze noticed one user instantly dislikes every new video and accuses him of misusing AI.
key_stories.challenge: First experience with a consistent negative viewer.
key_stories.process: Discussed on-stream, joked about ‘666slut’ tweet, kept development focus.
key_stories.outcome: Motivation unaffected; sees it as ‘exciting’ milestone of popularity.
key_stories.key_quote: I have taken notes that we have our first real hater… this is exciting.
